title: Former pro Phil Gaimon hit with $150,000 medical bill after crash
content:
Joe Robinson
2 Aug 2021

One bike crash sees the YouTuber facing huge medical bills despite insurance

Former pro cyclist turned YouTuber Phil Gaimon is feeling the sting of the American healthcare system after being left with a $150,000 bill despite having health insurance.

Despite having primary and secondary insurance cover, complications saw Gaimon slapped with $150,000 of the $200,000 bill, with American broadcaster CBS retelling the cyclist's story to highlight the spiralling medical costs for Americans.

Gaimon's nightmare began when suffered a crash at a velodrome in Trexlertown, Pennsylvania which left him unconscious and with seven broken bones in 2019.

The American was then rushed to the Lehigh Valley Hospital in Allentown, Pennsylvania for emergency surgery on his collarbone which was followed by a second surgery at a hosptial in New York, which Gaimon described as 'completely necessary' due to being in a 'tremendous pain all around'.

Then, while at home recovering from the crash and subsequent surgeries, the bills began to mount.

'They hit you with the bills when you're literally least capable of handling anything. I get a stack of bills every month. I get collection notices every day,' explained Gaimon to CBS.

Initially, Gaimon's insurance covered $52,000 of the work however the costs continued to rise as he realised he had been hit by what one expert described as the 'three big landmines' of hospital billing in the United States despite believing that he was fully insured. 

'Hospital billing is filled with landmines,' expert Dr. Elizabeth Rosenthal, editor-in-chief of Kaiser Health News, told CBS. 'And Phil hit three of them – out-of-network hospitals, high costs, and here's the biggy in his case – insurance from one state often doesn't work very well in another.'

Retrospectively, Gaimon discovered that the Lehigh Valley Hospital had marked his shoulder surgery down as 'elective' rather than 'emergency', hiking his costs, and that it was also in the state of Pennsylvania which has different billing laws to California where his insurer is based.

Gaimon, who is still attempting to persuade primary insurer Health Net to cover more of his bills, called the system 'a gamble'.

'This could happen to anybody at any time – where you can just wake up in a hospital and then later find out you owe them $150,000. I wish I knew that getting health insurance was still, essentially, a gamble.'
